justification: "WM tasks were adapted versions of the alpha span, numerical memory updating, and spatial n-back tasks" – identifying Alpha Span as one of the tasks used to assess WM performance.
Under "Numerical Memory Updating" the article describes participants memorising and updating digits and states that accuracy on this task was the WM performance measure.
The "Spatial 3-Back" section explains that participants judged whether a dot matched the one three steps earlier and that accuracy served as the WM score.
In the WM transfer section the paper notes: "Animal Span… six names of animals were shown… Average accuracy was used as the performance score," marking it as a WM measure.
"Spatial Memory Updating… the resulting end positions had to be clicked on… average accuracy was used for scoring," indicating this task operationalised WM.
The "Numerical 3-Back" description states that two-choice 3-back decisions were made and average accuracy was the performance score, treating it as a WM indicator.

measured_by: Drift rate from letters consonant-vowel choice reaction task
justification: "The three perceptual decision tasks required classifying letters (as consonants or vowels)… drift rates significantly increased…" showing that drift rate derived from the letters CRT indexes evidence-accumulation efficiency.

measured_by: Drift rate from digits odd-even choice reaction task
justification: For the digits CRT the paper reports systematic changes in drift rate, treating this parameter as the measure of evidence-accumulation efficiency.

measured_by: Drift rate from figures symmetric-asymmetric choice reaction task
justification: The figures CRT section likewise presents drift rate estimates and their relations, indicating this parameter operationalises the construct of evidence accumulation efficiency.
"Transfer tasks included… 27 tasks from the paper-and-pencil Berlin Intelligence Structure Test (BIS test…)" identifying the BIS as the instrument used to gauge fluid intelligence.
